docs.snippet: More than 130 Republican and Democratic members of Congress asked President Bush on Wednesday to persuade the World Trade Organization to delay the phase-out of a global quota system on textiles and garments.    The administration swiftly rejected...
docs.lead_paragraph: More than 130 Republican and Democratic members of Congress asked President Bush on Wednesday to persuade the World Trade Organization to delay the phase-out of a global quota system on textiles and garments. The administration swiftly rejected the request, which would mean breaking a 10-year-old global agreement to end the quotas on Jan. 1, 2005.
docs.abstract: More than 130 Republican and Democratic members of Congress ask Pres Bush to persuade World Trade Organization to delay phase-out of global quota system on textiles and garments; administration rejects request, which would mean breaking 10-year-old global agreement to end quotas on Jan 1, 2005; American textile and apparel manufacturing industry officials say ending quotas could lead to wide-ranging realignment of industry and spell disaster for textile and apparel industries in dozens of nations; Congressional members, in letter to Bush, say China is biggest threat, accusing it of 'unfair trade practices to heavily subsidize its exports'; adds US textile sector stands to lose almost 650,000 jobs; photo (M)

headline.main: White House Shuns Role on Textile Quotas

docs.snippet: According to press reports, military doctors and nurses who examined prisoners at Abu Ghraib treated swollen genitals, prescribed painkillers, stitched wounds, and recorded evidence of the abuses going on around them. Under international law -- as...
docs.lead_paragraph: According to press reports, military doctors and nurses who examined prisoners at Abu Ghraib treated swollen genitals, prescribed painkillers, stitched wounds, and recorded evidence of the abuses going on around them. Under international law -- as well as the standards of common decency -- these medical professionals had a duty to tell those in power what they saw. Instead, too often, they returned the victims of torture to the custody of their victimizers. Rather than putting a stop to torture, they tacitly abetted it, by patching up victims and staying silent.
docs.abstract: Prof M Gregg Bloche Op-Ed article sees need to investigate United States doctors who treated Abu Ghraib victims; notes that press reports show that military doctors and nurses who examined prisoners at Abu Ghraib treated swollen genitals, prescribed painkillers, stitched wounds, and recorded evidence of abuses going on around them; argues that under international law--as well as standards of common decency--these medical professionals had duty to tell those in power what they saw; says that instead, they returned victims of torture to custody of their victimizers (M)

headline.main: After Abu Ghraib; Physician, Turn Thyself In

keywords.name: subject
keywords.value: WAR CRIMES, GENOCIDE AND CRIMES AGAINST HUMANITY

docs.snippet: Leonel Brizola, the former governor of Rio de Janeiro state and a veteran leftist whose role in trying to head off a military coup in the early 1960's made him a towering figure in Brazilian politics, died Monday night at a hospital near his home in...
docs.lead_paragraph: Leonel Brizola, the former governor of Rio de Janeiro state and a veteran leftist whose role in trying to head off a military coup in the early 1960's made him a towering figure in Brazilian politics, died Monday night at a hospital near his home in the Copacabana district in Rio de Janeiro. He was 82. The cause was a heart attack, officials of São Lucas Hospital announced. He had checked in earlier in the day with a serious cold and a lung infection, they said.
docs.abstract: Leonel Brizola, leftist former governor of Rio de Janeiro state and towering figure in Brazilian politics, dies at age 82; photo (M)

headline.main: Leonel Brizola, 82, Dies; Opposed Military Rule in Brazil

docs.snippet: SIR MIX-A-LOT'S salacious 1992 hit ''Baby Got Back'' blasted from the house stereo system at 7 Bamboo, a karaoke bar here, on a Friday night. Two bar regulars momentarily turned rap stars, billed as Toqer and Woody, gyrated on the corner stage and...
docs.lead_paragraph: SIR MIX-A-LOT'S salacious 1992 hit ''Baby Got Back'' blasted from the house stereo system at 7 Bamboo, a karaoke bar here, on a Friday night. Two bar regulars momentarily turned rap stars, billed as Toqer and Woody, gyrated on the corner stage and praised big behinds as the audience joined in with off-key wails. It was great entertainment for the regulars at the 'Boo, as well as for 14 others who were watching the performance online from as far as St. Louis, Uruguay and Australia and as near as the next town.
docs.abstract: Web-based television broadcasting has been vastly improved by increased broadband access and enhanced streaming technologies; more than 100 independent stations cover variety of programming interests; accessing programs explained; photos (M)

headline.main: Internet TV: Don't Touch That Mouse!

docs.snippet: HOCKEY  Quenneville Hired by Avalanche        Joel Quenneville, who was an assistant coach under Marc Crawford in 1995-96 and played a role in the franchise's first Stanley Cup championship, was hired to coach the Colorado Avalanche yesterday. He...
docs.lead_paragraph: HOCKEY Quenneville Hired by Avalanche Joel Quenneville, who was an assistant coach under Marc Crawford in 1995-96 and played a role in the franchise's first Stanley Cup championship, was hired to coach the Colorado Avalanche yesterday. He replaces Tony Granato, who will become his assistant.
docs.abstract: Colorado Avalanche names Joel Quenneville as head coach (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: TENNIS Zabaleta Wins Swedish Open Mariano Zabaleta, the defending champion, outlasted the French Open champion Gaston Gaudio, 6-1, 4-6, 7-6 (4), to win an all-Argentine final yesterday at the Swedish Open in Bastad.

docs.snippet: PRO FOOTBALL  Cardinals Forfeit Workouts      The Arizona Cardinals have forfeited the final week of their off-season workouts after a group of players complained to the players union that the team had violated league rules by working the players too...
docs.lead_paragraph: PRO FOOTBALL Cardinals Forfeit Workouts The Arizona Cardinals have forfeited the final week of their off-season workouts after a group of players complained to the players union that the team had violated league rules by working the players too hard.
docs.abstract: Arizona Cardinals forfeit final week of workouts in response to complaints that team workouts were too hard and too long (S)

docs.snippet: SOCCER  Paraguay Upsets Brazil      Fredy Bareiro scored in the 71st minute last night as Paraguay upset Brazil, 2-1, to win Group C in Copa America in Arequipa, Peru. Paraguay will play Uruguay next in a quarterfinal game Sunday. Brazil will face...
docs.lead_paragraph: SOCCER Paraguay Upsets Brazil Fredy Bareiro scored in the 71st minute last night as Paraguay upset Brazil, 2-1, to win Group C in Copa America in Arequipa, Peru. Paraguay will play Uruguay next in a quarterfinal game Sunday. Brazil will face Mexico. Costa Rica, which eliminated Chile, 2-1, on an injury-time goal yesterday, will play Colombia on Saturday. The other quarterfinal match features Peru against Argentina on Saturday. HOCKEY Gomez Replaces Roenick
docs.abstract: Paraguay defeats Brazil, 2-1, in Copa America (S)

docs.snippet: GOLF  Dunn Finally Gets a Victory On the L.P.G.A. Tour      With a clap of thunder, Moira Dunn finally ended her streak of 244 tournaments without a victory.    Dunn, putting out moments after lightning flashed in the distance, birdied the 16th and...
docs.lead_paragraph: GOLF Dunn Finally Gets a Victory On the L.P.G.A. Tour With a clap of thunder, Moira Dunn finally ended her streak of 244 tournaments without a victory. Dunn, putting out moments after lightning flashed in the distance, birdied the 16th and 17th holes to win the Giant Eagle L.P.G.A. Classic yesterday in Vienna, Ohio.
docs.abstract: Moira Dunn wins Giant Eagle LPGA Classic; photo (S)

docs.snippet: SOCCER  Argentina Beats Colombia To Advance to Copa Finals      Argentina beat the defending champion Colombia, 3-0, last night in Lima, Peru, to advance to the finals of Copa America for the first time since 1993. Argentina won the title that year...
docs.lead_paragraph: SOCCER Argentina Beats Colombia To Advance to Copa Finals Argentina beat the defending champion Colombia, 3-0, last night in Lima, Peru, to advance to the finals of Copa America for the first time since 1993. Argentina won the title that year for the 14th time.
docs.abstract: Argentina defeats Colombia, 3-0, to advance to finals of Copa America (S)
